dialogues.text: I miss Joey. I wish Joey was here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you just call him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him how you feel -- you miss him. Tell him you're sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pauze)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ok, all right. Telephone's in the hall. Dial his number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VICKIE goes to the pay phone in the hall, and dials long distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE is nervous, but follows VICKIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the number starts to ring, VICKIE hands the phone to JAKE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello... hello...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE can't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this, a joke? Hello... Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE can't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if there's somebody listenin', their mother's a fuckin' whore who takes it in the ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a click as JOEY hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE stands there, and finally hangs up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE gulps down the last of his Scotch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing his monologue)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shoulda never hit my brother. Afterwards I was sorry. Now every time I need somethin' I gotta go shoppin' for it! A psychiatrist once told me, "When you hit your brother you're really hittin' your mother but you can't admit it to yourself." He's really crazy. I woulda never hit my mother. I mean, only in self-defense! A lot of people wanta know who was the best guy I ever fought. Let's see... there was that one I fought twice... the other Frenchman... you know who I mean... (having trouble pronouncing the name)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Dauthuille! He was tough, but I beat him... I had to! I mean, how would it sound losin' to a guy whose name you can't even pronounce? But... Robinson. I can say that alright. I fought Sugar Ray so many times it's a wonder I don't have diabetes! Linda... get me another drink! Linda's the most popular waitress here... you can tell by her tips! She's the kinda girl I go for. You oughta see the ones I get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LINDA brings him another Scotch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Thanks, babe. She's a nice kid. She'll only do it with a guy if she really likes him. She's got a lot in common with Will Rogers -- never met a man she didn't like! ... I was talkin' about Sugar Ray. Some of you think I was better than him... but you know, it's a toss up. Except the last fight... February 14, 1951.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE sips his drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valentine's Day. The anniversary of the St. Valentine's Massacre. Robinson didn't use a machine gun but it was still a massacre...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE takes another drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I was doin' okay at first. In fact, by the end of the fifth round I really had him worried -- he thought he killed me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LENORE, JOEY's wife, watches the 6th Robinson-LaMotta fig on JOEY's new television console.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOEY walks by on his way to another room, but stops to wa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LENORE is not a fight fan, but is caught up in the fight, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at that. The sonofabitch is outboxing Robinson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe he's getting that jab in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bell sounds, and a Pabst commercial comes on:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Friend, the quality that has carried Pabst Blue Ribbon around the world is yours for the asking. Next time that friendly bartender says, 'What'll you have?' give him the answer the whole world gives, Pabst Blue Ribbon!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY is wiping JAKE off in his corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ain't hurting me, but I can't get him down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't talk. Keep at it. Jab, jab, jab. You're ahead on points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the other, SUGAR RAY'S TRAINER pats down ROBINSON's pompadour as he says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's going, Sugar. He's old. He ain't Jake LaMotta no more. Make your move, Sugar. Kill him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROBINSON nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bell sounds and the FIGHTERS step onto the canvas. Th look at each other before the boxing starts -- they both the inevitable outcome. ROBINSON smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROBINSON makes his move. His arms are a blur, swinging rapidly but accurately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOEY and LENORE are suddenly silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LaMotta's on queer street, but he's still standing. Robinson throws a right, a left, a right, a right and a right again! How can LaMotta stay on his feet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the TV, WE SEE that ROBINSON has JAKE up against the ropes. He's giving JAKE a pier six beating. It's the Fox fight for real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE's face is so soaked in blood that it's impossible to pinpoint the cuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No man can take this kind of punishment. LaMotta is just a rag doll now. God knows what's holding him up. This is an historic beating. Sugar Rav staggers LaMotta with a left and comes across with a blackjack punch to the champion's head. The referee is stepping in, Robinson has LaMotta on the ropes. That's it! Sugar Ray Robinson, former welterweight champion, has taken the middleweight crown from Jake LaMota.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the REFEREE stops the fight, JOEY sighs with relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAMOTTA, a bloody and beaten fighter, walks over to the victorious ROBINSON and puts his arm on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never knocked me down. You could never knock me down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROBINSON, receiving congratulations from every direction, takes time to turn to JAKE and say:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ESTABLISHING SHOT. The house is quite large, and has beautiful landscaping and a swimming pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE, wearing sportclothes that can't hide his paunch, an VICKIE, wearing a dress and looking her best, sit in the living room with their THREE CHILDREN (the TWO BOYS, and a GIRL, about two years old).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A still PHOTOGRAPHER clicks pictures of JAKE and VICKIE a TWO REPORTERS talk with JAKE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm pulling out of next Wednesday's TV bout 'cause I can't make the weight. I'm fighting at light heavyweight, and I still can't make the weight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does that mean...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means I'm through with boxing. I'm tired with tryin' to make the weight anymore. I'm sick of thinkin' about weight, weight, weight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sound bitter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should I be bitter? Boxing's been good to me. I got a nice house, three kids, a beautiful wife -- take a picture of her. Vickie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VICKIE poses dutifully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't she beautiful? Coulda been Mrs. America if I didn't pull her outa the contest. Didn't want her wearing a swimsuit for nobody but me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think of Jake's retirement, Mrs. LaMotta?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE cuts in:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I also bought a club on Collins Avenue, and I'm gonna open it real soon. Know what I'm gonna call it? "Jake LaMotta's."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE, an empty glass in his hand, stands on the bar platf He's wearing a white tuxedo jacket with a red rose in the lapel. His tuxedo shirt is stained. He continues his monologue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valentine's Day. The anniversary of the St. Valentine's Day Massacre. Robinsin didn't use a machine gun but it was still a massacre... (takes another drink)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I was doin' okay at first. In fact, by the end of the fifth round I really had him worried --- he thought he killed me. You know, I could keep tellin' you this brilliant material all night -- but you'd only laugh. Now I'm gonna sing. -- Any requests? I mean, besides "don't"! (then to piano player)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- In the key of H. (then to audience)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're laughin'. Give me the right key and I'll play in anybody's flat! I sing for a reason. When I finish, you'll be so sobered up, we'll sell a lot of booze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE's onstage version of "That's Entertainment" differs the backstage version. It's not just that he's a little d -- no, his voice is defiant, sadly defiant. He is singing the PATRONS rather than to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "When the fighter's not engaged in his employment, his employment, although he was Champ and quite the rage, he must go somewhere else to seek employment, seek employment. So what does he do? He goes upon the stage and meets his true adversaries, all you members of the human race. But a fighter's life is not a bowl of cherries, still I'd rather have an egg than a fist upon my face... That's Entertainment!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE brings the BAND to a crescendo with a wave of his ha then silences it. The spotlight goes out and there is a hearty round of applause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE receives the kisses, glad handshakes and congratulat of the PATRONS as he works his way around the club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE's new friends love him. They are PARTY GIRLS, SPORTS FIGURES, COLUMNISTS, MOBSTERS, B ACTORS, and OTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE poses for a still with TWO BUXOM YOUNG LOVELIES. ONE GIRL giggles as he fondles her. After the flash goes off, GIRLS admire his "small, delicate" hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE steps over to a table and greets J.R., a newspaper columnist, and his COMPANIONS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: J.R., glad you could make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were great, Jake. Just like old times. Good thing Sugar Ray wasn't here tonight. Oh Jake, this is State's Attorney Bronson and his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE shakes his hand, then holds it up -- showing an empt palm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (joking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, empty! Heh, heh! Oh, I didn't mean that. If I don't give your husband no money, he won't have enough to buy you a drink. To show you I'm a nice guy, this one's on me. The last one was your payment for this month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRONSON is embarrassed. He doesn't think the joke is funn but he manages a smile. His WIFE gives a nervous laugh. J leans over and kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a good sport, lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw you fight Bob Satterfield in '46, Jake. In Chicago. You were great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I really cleaned up on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your wife, Jake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think I'd let her in a place like this with guys like you hangin' around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE feigns a few jabs, and they all laugh. He walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As JAKE leaves, J.R. whispers to his FRIEND:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ought to see his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE steps over to a table where some of the "BOYS" are sitting. RICKY is the Miami 1956 version of Salvy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Ricky, glad you came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't miss it, Jake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE calls a WAITRESS over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, honey, give these fellas a round on me. I can tell they're gonna be regular customers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WAITRESS says to a clearly underaged GIRL:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have to ask for your I.D.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE leans over and gives the young GIRL a long kiss on t lips. She enthusiastically reciprocates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whew! Any girl that can kiss like that can drink in my club any time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all laugh as JAKE moves on. The life of the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE, hungover, his tux wrinkled, walks out of the club t the adjacent parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VICKIE is sitting in her yellow Cadillac outside the Club The curbside window is halfway up. She calls to him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE, chagrined, steps over to the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I had to work late last night. Slept at the club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm leaving your Jake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, what else is new?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. This time it's true. I didn't bother to tell you until I had everything worked out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE tries to open the door. It's locked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open the door, Vickie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I won't talk to you where you can use your hands on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, c'mon. Don't say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a lawyer, Jake. We're getting a divorce. I'm getting custody of the kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, c'mon, Vick --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sick of it. I can't watch you this way. You're too drunk all the time. There's too many girls. I can't... I don't wanna talk about it. I made up my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE tries to reach in the window, but VICKIE hits the po switch, closing it and catching his hand. She now has to to him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got three days to get your stuff out of the house. After that, the cops will be there. I have the kids with me. I never want to see you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VICKIE turns her face and drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE grabs at the Cadillac, but it is bigger and stronger than him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE is left alone in the parking lot. The car is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE has an office above the lounge. Ever since VICKIE le it's also been his apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is a mess. JAKE sends his laundry out when he r out of clean clothes. Dirty socks, shorts and shirts are scattered randomly. Empty whiskey bottles on the desk, em beer cans in the wastebasket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go, Jake, wake up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? Whadda ya mean, get up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (showing badge)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're from...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know where you're from. You guys look the same every place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wanna talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't run the joint. They just told me to bring you in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, get dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE hunts for his clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I'm a big tax payer down here. Don't that entitle me to some information what this is all about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SECOND DEPUTY shows JAKE a photo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You recognize this girl? She been in the club?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She says you introduced her to men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I introduced a lot of people to men. So what? What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's fourteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE UP of picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE, wearing a suit, walks up to the door and pushes the bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VICKIE opens the door and looks at him over the chain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vickie, open up. I need to come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you drunk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Open the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE tries to touch her face through the doorway crack, b she steps back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Vick. I won't bother you. I'm out on bail. You can send the kids next door. I just gotta pick one thing up, then I'll get outa here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VICKIE thinks a moment, then opens the door and lets JAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids are sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promise I just gotta pick up one thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, just don't make any noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE walks directly past VICKIE into the living room. VIC watches from a safe distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE removes his jewel-studded championship belt from the glass bookcase and carries it into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the kitchen, he takes a hammer and screwdriver out of drawer, places the belt on the counter top, and starts digging the jewels out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VICKIE appears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need ten thousand dollars. My lawyer says if we can spread ten thousand bucks around, we can get the case dropped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they don't have a case against you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (digging at the belt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kiddin'? Did you ever see a 14-year-old testify in court? Did you see the papers? "LaMotta on Vice Rap." Everybody likes a shot at the Champ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake, be careful! What're you doing to the belt?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't make no difference no more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't you get the money from your friends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What friends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE, frustrated by his task, turns the belt over and ham at it. The jewels scatter across the counter top and floo JAKE collects the jewels and puts them in his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE stands at the counter of a small jewelry store. The JEWELER examines the stones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you also wish to sell the Championship Belt, Mr. LaMotta?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it. Those are the jewels that were in the belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But where's the belt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want the jewels or the belt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both. These stones are worth about fifteen hudred dollars, but the belt of a champion is a very rare item. The belt with the stones untouched would have been worth near five thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE seems to despair of the whole thing: the belt, the attempt to raise 10 g's, the vice case, his life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE places a call from a booth outside the jewelry store

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't raise the ten thousand. Fuck 'em. Let 'em put me on trial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same as Scene 1.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE, 42 years old, continues to rehearse. He is seated across from a mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So there I am in the can... and not the one that says "gentlemen" on the door. I'm talkin' about jail! Down south! I mean, jail up north is gotta be like summer camp compared to jail down in cracker country. And if you're a guy like me, you ain't got a chance in a place like that. Especially if you're Italian... you come from the Bronx... and you're an ex-champ. As soon as they saw me... soon as they heard me... I know I'm in trouble. To me, they got an accent, and to them, I got an accent! You gotta get the picture -- I'm big, I got small hands, I walk like I'm still in the ring... the balls of my feet pop up and down, you know... and whenever I get the chance, I read a lot. So naturally, takin' all this into sideration, they figure it adds up to one thing -- I'm queer! Now I didn't mind too much when they called me "Queer" or "Mr. Tough Guy" or "Yankee Punk"... But one day these screws got to me... I was workin' on the work gang, pickin' up some trees that were knocked down by a storm or somethin' and puttin' 'em on this truck. All of a sudden... one of the trees slipped and fell on me and pinned me to the ground. I'm lyin' there with a tree across my chest! This screw walks over, takin' his time, he looks down at me and says, "Well, Champ Pimp... you lyin' down on the job again?"! They got a great sense of humor when they're standin' there with a gun in their arms and you got a tree on your chest! So I look up at him and say, "Oh, this tree... it fell on me." And he says, "Oh, I'm sorry... If I'd have known, I would've yelled 'timber'" I said, "Hey, look... it hurts. I think maybe I broke somethin'!" He says, "Well, whaddaya know... Champ PImp's got himself a boo-boo." Then I got as stupid as him. I said, "If I'm Champ Pimp... how 'bout givin' me the money you made last night?"! Then another screw comes over and says, "This Yankee creep givin' you trouble?" -- What kind of trouble? What am I gonna do -- hit 'em with the tree? Now anybody else in their right mind would've said, "No sir, I wouldn't think of giving any of you gentlemen trouble... I just want to serve my time and get the hell out of here as soon as I can." That's anybody else. When I said it... it was a little different. "You stupid cracker... take your hands off me or I'll get up and kick your brains out -- but first you gotta bend over so I can find 'em!" Next thing I know I'm in the hole. Solitary confinement. All my life I had guys in my corner yellin' "Go get 'em, jake... kill 'em! You're the greatest." Now there's nobody rootin' for me. But it wasn't so bad. I learned things there. I learned how to scratch a calendar on the wall. I never knew how to do that before. Now I know. Monday is one scratch. Tuesday is two scratches. Wednesday is three scratches. And so on. Except for Sundays. Sundays is no scratches. Sundays rested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA TRACKS down the lonely corridors of the Dade County Prison. Empty faces stare out from behind the bars

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE is led down a long corridor by TWO GUARDS. His hands legs are manacled and chained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GUARDS, redneck screws both, take special pleasure in working JAKE over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They take JAKE to the "Hole" -- solitary confinement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ONE of the GUARDS unmanacles JAKE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both GUARDS push JAKE into the cell and slam the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thin slit provides the only light in JAKE's cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rough cement walls are covered with obscure graffiti. 8x8x8 room features only a cot and a toilet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is mostly darkness. Sounds are more tangible her than sights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE SEE JAKE's body as it passes through the slit of light

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE crouches into the corner away from the light. As WE JAKE's face, the following MONTAGE images appear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (There will be contrasting sound effects accompanying the images: for example, the image of JAKE hitting VICKIE mig be accompanied by the sounds from a love scene between th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A) 1940s black and white pornography: partially clothed m and women engaged in explicit sex acts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: B) Boxing magazines: fighters' beaten and bloody faces. A body building ad: Charles Atlas raises his muscled biceps

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C) Li'l Abner comics; Daisy Mae's tits seem about to fall free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D) Reprise from earlier scene: Back in JAKE and IRMA's ol apartment, JOEY, using a towel as a glove, punches JAKE i the face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: E) A 1934 "OLDER GIRL" sashays into the candy store in flickering 8mm black and white footage. WE SEE ohter Bron PRETEEN GIRLS walking, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: F) At Shorehaven pool, JAKE and JOEY, in bathing suits, a sleeping in the sun next to each other. OTHER BATHERS are around, also taking in the sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: G) Reprise from earlier scene: As in D, JOEY hits JAKE in face again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE SEE again the image of JAKE's face as he sits in his c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MONTAGE continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: H) JANIRO's face at the weigh-in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I) JAKE throws JANIRO a kiss at the weigh-in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: J) JAKE punches in JANIRO's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: K) A naked GIRL stands in the doorway of a bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: L) JAKE lies in bed with IRMA staring at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M) VICKIE's pretty young face DOUBLE EXPOSES with SUGAR R ROBINSON's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: N) DR. PINTO injects novacaine into JAKE's fists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O) Sitting in his corner of the ring, JAKE spits blood in pail...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P) Still in JAKE's corner: JOEY wipes off his brother's bloody face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Q) Still in JAKE's corner: There is an open cut over JAKE eye. JOEY, rushing against time, sucks the blood from the wound as DR. PINTO begins to examine it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: R) Still in JAKE's corner: JOEY puts the mouthpiece in JA mouth. (SLOW MOTION)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: S) JAKE wins over CERDAN. JOEY, overenthusiastic, hits JA on the back of the head a little too hard. JAKE gives JOE quick look, but JOEY just embraces him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: T) On a bed, a GIRL is going down on JOEY. The GIRL turns looks up at JAKE. It's LINDA, the waitress from his club. JAKE stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: U) JAKE's fist hits LINDA's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: V) VICKIE playfully bends JAKE's hand back, pretending to break it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: W) JAKE hits LINDA again. She cries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: X) Repeat image N: DR. PINTO injects novocaine into JAKE' fists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE SEE again the image of JAKE's face as he sits in his c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MONTAGE continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y) VICKIE is in her underwear in a bedroom. A pair of bla arms come in and embrace her body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Z) CLOSE UP of JAKE; he reacts to this. He's in the ring SUGAR RAY. He knocks SUGAR RAY out of the ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AA) VICKIE again. JAKE approaches her from behind, pulls head back by her hair, and slaps her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB) THE ANNOUNCER points to SUGAR RAY as the winner. (Different fight.) CAMERA PANS to RAY, victorious, his ar up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CC) A bloodied JAKE comes over to SUGAR RAY and embraces

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE ARE BACK WITH JAKE in the cell. He slowly starts to ba his head against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (murmuring)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, why, why? (with each bang of his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a man, I'm a man. I'm no faggot. I'm not a faggot. Ma, why? What do they want? My cock's not enough. What do they want from me? Why? Ma? Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE is now smashing the wall with all his strength -- vicious body punches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, why, why me? You took it away from me. They took everything away. What do they want from me? What the fuck do they want from me? I ain't bad. I ain't bad. I'm not that guy. I'm not that guy. I'm not a monster. I'm not an animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE breaks his knuckles; the pain and blood are unbearab

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE collapses to the concrete floor. His hands are smash He cries, then sobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not like that. Please. I'm not like that. Please. Please. Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We begin to hear: JAKE doing a monologue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so, as Shakespeare said, I've been down so low there's nowhere else to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Metropole is a club on 7th Avenue off Times Square.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE LAMOTTA, 36 years old and wearing a hip Fifties suit continues his monologue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except here, gentlemen, with you bums. I call you "gentlemen"... but you know what you really are! You know, this place used to be pretty exclusive... now they got bouncers outside to throw the drunks in! My first night here I said to the boss, "Where's the toilet?" -- He said, "You're in it!" By the way, this engagement is just a stepping stone for me. If I do good here, I'm ready to get out of the business!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CROWD starts to shout: "Get the fuck off the stage!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, OK, I know what you're waitin' for -- and from the looks of you, you been waitin' for it for a long time. I had my own joint in Miami Beach once... it was too high-class for you guys... we had a 50-cent minimum charge just to keep out the riff-raff!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CROWD continues to shout, as before, also shouting: "Bring out the girls!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, sorry. Here's your girls. (grabs his crotch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, she's here... just like it's advertised out front. She's come back. A girl who's seen the Lower Depths... who's been as far as I have in that direction. She's on her way back up now... give you an idea how low she was! Let's give her a warm welcome... make her glad she's back, boys. -- Miss Emma 48's!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE gets off the stage as MISS EMMA 48's goes into her dance. He goes over to the bar and gets a drink. SEVERAL OLDER MEN in T-shirts - a disreputable looking lot - are the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Club is closing. JAKE and EMMA, the stripper, come ou and walk by a delicatessen on their way to a parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE sees his brother JOEY enter the delicatessen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, sweetie, be a good girl. Here's some money. Take a cab. Go home by yourself. Just wanna walk around a little, sort of unwind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will I see you later?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I dunno... I'll call you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE goes to the parking lot entrance as EMMA gets into a cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about twenty minutes later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOLLY INTO A MEDIUM SHOT of JAKE waiting by the parking l He looks at the delicatessen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOEY finally comes out carrying a paper bag. Not noticing JAKE, he walks right past him to his car which is parked the rear of the outdoor lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Joey --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE walks towards JOEY with his hand outstretched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOEY looks at JAKE. Silence. JOEY turns his back and star to get into his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE runs over to JOEY and grabs his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Joey, no. Look, wait a minute, please --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOEY looks at JAKE like he's shit, throws JAKE's hand off shoulder, and starts to get into his car again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, Joey --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE stops JOEY from getting into his car. He puts his ha on JOEY's shoulder again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. You're perfectly right. You got every right in the world to hate my guts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOEY pulls away from JAKE's hand, and tries to put the pa bag into the front seat of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, please. I know I was a cocksucker. You're right. I shoulda never raised my hands to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOEY half pushes JAKE away, and begins to get into his ca again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE pulls JOEY by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Joey, listen to me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE pulls too hard, causing JOEY to drop the paper bag t his feet. The containers of coffee and tea in the bag bre open and splatter JOEY's pants legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOEY stares down at his pants, then up at JAKE. Suddenly, belts JAKE with a left and a right to the jaw. JAKE is ta by surprise, and backs off to get his own hands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOEY keeps pouring it on. JAKE drops his hands and takes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead. (gets punched)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hit me again. (gets punched)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I deserve it... (gets punched)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pay me back... (gets punched)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More... (gets punched)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOEY stops in mid-punch and stares at JAKE. He can't figu it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE nods and tries to smile, but starts to cry instead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More. Go ahead, Joey. I deserve it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOEY pauses, then finally throws a very weak punch to JAK shoulder. He leaves his hand there -- then, uncurls his fist -- and finally puts his hand around JAKE's neck as tears start t fill his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOEY hugs JAKE close to him, crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hug each other, both crying. They don't say anything

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The theater lights are flashing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This may not be Broadway, but it's a long way from the Metropole. The entrance to the Barbizon looks out on the corner of 6th Avenue and Central Park South.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stand-up billboard in front of the theater advertises " Evening with Jake LaMotta." The billboard also lists the authors whose works will be performed: Paddy Chayevsky, R Serling, Shakespeare, Bud Schulberg, Tennessee Williams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same as Scenes One and Eighty-One.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE is alone preparing to go onstage. He rehearses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I'm not a philosopher or anything like that but I been around a little and the way I look at it is -- We're, all of us, lookin' for the same thing: a shot at the title. No matter what you wanta be... you wanta shot at bein' the best. Well, I had mine and it'll always be in the record books... it don't make no difference what happens to me from here on in -- I got my shot and that's a fact. Some guys weren't that lucky... like the one Marlon Brando played in "On the Waterfront" -- an up and comer who's now a down and outer. You remember... there was this scene in the back of the car with his brother Charlie, a small-time racket guy, and it went somethin' like this -- "It wasn't him, Charlie. It was you. You 'member that night in the Garden you came down my dressing room and said. 'Kid, this ain't your night. We're going for the price on Wilson.' You 'member that? 'This ain't your night!' My night -- I coulda taken Wilson apart! So what happens? He gets the title shot outdoors on the ballpark, and what do I get? A one-way ticket to Palookaville. I never was no good after that night. It was like a peak you reach. Then it went downhill. It was you, Charlie. You was my brother, Charlie. You shoulda looked out for me a little bit. You shoulda taken care of me just a little bit so I wouldn't have to take them dives for the short end money... You don't understand! I coulda had class. I coulda been a contender. I coulda been somebody -- instead of a bum, which is what I am. Let's face it. It was you, Charlie."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shadow goes by the frame; it's a STAGEHAND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Jake, how you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shadow exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long do I have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shadow pops in again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About five minutes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shadow exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE pauses, then starts to shadow-box in his dressing ro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His breath comes in quick gasps. His feet pop up and down like they were on canvas. His tiny fists jerk forward wit short bursts of light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still alive. Still a contender. A 42-year-old man fightin for his shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA DOLLIES into a FULL SHOT of his fists as they the empty air -- in and out of the frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This quote appears: (Music in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Verily, verily I say unto thee, Except a man be born again, He can not enter into the kingdom of heaven..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA goes into DARKNESS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The END CREDITS roll up.
